<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 276, 324, 292]]<|/det|>
## FURTHER MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 277, 905, 292]]<|/det|>
9231/13  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 300, 368, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 1 Further Pure Mathematics 1  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[782, 301, 905, 316]]<|/det|>
May/June 2022  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[841, 326, 905, 341]]<|/det|>
2 hours  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 393, 370]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 393, 400]]<|/det|>
You will need: List of formulae (MF19)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 230, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 275, 450]]<|/det|>
Answer all questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 450, 760, 466]]<|/det|>
Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 466, 808, 482]]<|/det|>
Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 482, 562, 497]]<|/det|>
Write your answer to each question in the space provided.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 498, 485, 512]]<|/det|>
Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 513, 359, 527]]<|/det|>
Do not write on any bar codes.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 528, 868, 559]]<|/det|>
If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 560, 480, 575]]<|/det|>
You should use a calculator where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 575, 880, 606]]<|/det|>
You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 606, 860, 637]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 666, 220, 680]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 682, 384, 697]]<|/det|>
The total mark for this paper is 75.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 698, 730, 713]]<|/det|>
The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 78, 99, 98]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 78, 146, 98]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 75, 485, 101]]<|/det|>
Sketch the curve with equation \(y = \frac{x + 1}{x - 1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 78, 920, 98]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 375, 146, 393]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 364, 918, 406]]<|/det|>
Sketch the curve with equation \(y = \frac{\left|x\right| + 1}{\left|x\right| - 1}\) and find the set of values of \(x\) for which \(\left|\frac{x}{x}\right| + 1 < - 2\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 400, 920, 420]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 75, 96, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 75, 589, 94]]<|/det|>
The cubic equation \(x^{3} + 5x^{2} + 10x - 2 = 0\) has roots \(\alpha , \beta , \gamma .\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 106, 144, 125]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 106, 400, 125]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(\alpha^{2} + \beta^{2} + \gamma^{2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 106, 920, 125]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 82, 97, 102]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 76, 672, 107]]<|/det|>
A curve \(C\) has equation \(y = \frac{a x^{2} + x - 1}{x - 1}\), where \(a\) is a positive constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 112, 146, 131]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 112, 487, 133]]<|/det|>
Find the equations of the asymptotes of \(C\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 112, 920, 131]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 510, 186, 529]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 510, 621, 532]]<|/det|>
Show that there is no point on \(C\) for which \(1< y< 1 + 4a\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 512, 920, 532]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 82, 97, 102]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 479, 109]]<|/det|>
Let \(\mathbf{A} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & a \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}\), where \(a\) is a positive constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 115, 144, 134]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 114, 798, 134]]<|/det|>
State the type of the geometrical transformation in the \(x - y\) plane represented by \(\mathbf{A}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 115, 918, 134]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 208, 146, 227]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 208, 660, 227]]<|/det|>
Prove by mathematical induction that, for all positive integers \(n\),

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[443, 229, 556, 265]]<|/det|>
\[\mathbf{A}^{n} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & n a \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 240, 918, 259]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 78, 514, 112]]<|/det|>
Let \(\mathbf{B} = \begin{pmatrix} b & b \\ a^{-1} & a^{-1} \end{pmatrix}\), where \(b\) is a positive constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 117, 144, 135]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 117, 920, 152]]<|/det|>
Find the equations of the invariant lines, through the origin, of the transformation in the \(x - y\) plane represented by \(\mathbf{A}''\mathbf{B}\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 133, 920, 151]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 75, 92, 94]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 75, 771, 96]]<|/det|>
The curve \(C\) has Cartesian equation \(x^{2} + xy + y^{2} = a\), where \(a\) is a positive constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 106, 144, 125]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 102, 566, 127]]<|/det|>
Show that the polar equation of \(C\) is \(r^{2} = \frac{2a}{2 + \sin 2\theta}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 104, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 504, 186, 523]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 504, 445, 526]]<|/det|>
Sketch the part of \(C\) for \(0 \leqslant \theta \leqslant \frac{1}{4}\pi\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 504, 920, 523]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 74, 761, 96]]<|/det|>
The region \(R\) is enclosed by this part of \(C\), the initial line and the half-line \(\theta = \frac{1}{4}\pi\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 106, 144, 125]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 102, 910, 135]]<|/det|>
It is given that \(\sin 2\theta\) may be expressed as \(\frac{2\tan\theta}{1 + \tan^2\theta}\). Use this result to show that the area of \(R\) is

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[391, 159, 606, 198]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{1}{2} a\int_{0}^{\frac{1}{4}\pi}\frac{1 + \tan^{2}\theta}{1 + \tan\theta + \tan^{2}\theta}\mathrm{d}\theta\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 214, 688, 234]]<|/det|>
and use the substitution \(t = \tan \theta\) to find the exact value of this area.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 215, 920, 234]]<|/det|>
<mark>[8]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 97, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 495, 89]]<|/det|>
The position vectors of the points \(A, B, C, D\) are

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[240, 102, 757, 120]]<|/det|>
\[7\mathbf{i} + 4\mathbf{j} - \mathbf{k},\qquad 11\mathbf{i} + 3\mathbf{j},\qquad 2\mathbf{i} + 6\mathbf{j} + 3\mathbf{k},\qquad 2\mathbf{i} + 7\mathbf{j} + \lambda \mathbf{k}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 134, 220, 152]]<|/det|>
respectively.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 165, 146, 183]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 164, 920, 198]]<|/det|>
Given that the shortest distance between the line \(AB\) and the line \(CD\) is 3, show that \(\lambda^2 - 5\lambda + 4 = 0\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 180, 920, 198]]<|/det|>
<mark>[7]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 425, 91]]<|/det|>
Let \(\varPi_{1}\) be the plane \(ABD\) when \(\lambda = 1.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 425, 122]]<|/det|>
Let \(\varPi_{2}\) be the plane \(ABD\) when \(\lambda = 4.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 135, 144, 154]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 135, 181, 154]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 134, 811, 154]]<|/det|>
Write down an equation of \(\varPi_{1}\), giving your answer in the form \(\mathbf{r} = \mathbf{a} + s\mathbf{b} + t\mathbf{c}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 135, 918, 154]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 289, 180, 308]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 289, 771, 308]]<|/det|>
Find an equation of \(\varPi_{2}\), giving your answer in the form \(ax + by + cz = d\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 289, 920, 308]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 144, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 489, 91]]<|/det|>
Find the acute angle between \(\varPi_{1}\) and \(\varPi_{2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 72, 918, 91]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[433, 72, 564, 88]]<|/det|>
## Additional page  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 101, 920, 135]]<|/det|>
If you use the following page to complete the answer to any question, the question number must be clearly shown.
